text: Hi, everyone.

My name is Deb Wallace, and
I'm the executive director of Knowledge and
Library Services here at Harvard Business School.

And we're just delighted
to have you join us on. If you're in Boston, it's
kind of clouding over, and I think we're supposed
to get a bit of snow.

But we're delighted
that you're all here. I'd particularly like to
welcome our colleagues

from Harvard's Graduate School
of Education and Gutman Library, who helped us get the
word out about this very, very

special book. Thanks to Alex and Myanne
for all of your help. I'd also like to welcome
a number of colleagues

from the University of Toronto. Tom was slated to be in
Toronto last spring to talk

about the book with the HBS
Toronto Alumni Association,

and that had to be
canceled with a pandemic. So they've all-- Tom, they've
all been waiting patiently for you, so here we are.

We've got a contingent from
Toronto too, and my thanks to my friend and colleague
Carol Rolheiser

who helped us spread the word. We also have quite a stalwart
following from the HBS Boston

Alumni Club, the
association of Boston, and we were just delighted
to have you all here again.

So if this is your
first Books@Baker, we hope it's not your last. And we'll put the
link into the chat

of how you can stay on top
of all of the sessions. We usually do about one
a month, and so we'd

love to have you continue to
join us and become a regular.

But before I introduce Tom
and turn it over to him, just a little bit about how
we're going to run the session.

Tom, as you can see, is in
his office in Morgan Hall,

and he is going to take the
first part, 20 minutes or so, and talk about some of the
key concepts of the book.

And then I'm going to
ask him a few questions, and then we're going to move
into answering questions

that you may have. So you can put in a question
at any point in the chat.

Unfortunately, the
time probably won't allow us to get to
every single question, but we'll also look for
patterns in questions

and ask sort of questions--
a synthesis of questions if that makes sense
because we want

to try to engage with
you as much as possible. Please note that we are
recording the session,

and as soon as we have the
transcript of the conversation ready to go, we'll post the
session on the Baker Library

Books@Baker website so you can
go back and have a look at it again, or you can share
it with your colleagues.

We'll also send you a link,
everybody who's registered, a link to where that video
is and a set of the slides

so that you have that. So Tom's been incredibly
gracious in allowing

us to do both the recording
and share his slides. So we will wrap up
pretty close to 4:30

because, if you're like me,
you've been on Zoom all day, and you're even though this
will be a fantastic session,

about an hour is
almost all we can take. So we'll wrap up then, and then
we'll be back in touch with you

in how to access the recording. So it is my great
pleasure to introduce Tom.

For many of you,
especially HBS alumni, Tom doesn't need
an introduction,

but he's a professor
of management practice at Baker Foundation,
professor here

at Harvard Business School. He is a beloved
classroom teacher,

and so we couldn't ask
for a better person to talk about his
passion for teaching.

He's taught courses on
leadership development, organizational behavior,
managing human capital,

and career transformation,
and in both our MBA and our executive
education courses.

His previous book, Flying
Without a Net, something that I have not yet tried,
was recognized by the Amazon

publishing group as
one of the top 10 books written on leadership
in this century.

Tom is also a
prolific case writer. If you go to his faculty page
and just see the list of his

research and his publications,
you'll see that he co-authored the infamous Rob Parsons at
Morgan Stanley, which is--

anybody who's been at HBS,
alumni, MBA in particular,

you know this case. It's a fantastic case,
and he based on his work

when he was at Morgan Stanley
as chief development officer and managing director of
Morgan Stanley Group Inc.

So he'll be talking of
about that experience and how that weaves into
his thoughts about leaders

as teachers and
teachers as leaders. So as I said, you can learn more
about Tom's work on his faculty

page. Moriah's just put
that in the chat. I urge you to have a look there.

We also have a link to his
working knowledge articles, so that will give you a
little more background.
So, Tom, over to you. Thank you. Good morning.

Good afternoon. Good evening wherever you are. I'd like you to take you
back to an experience I

had about 12 years ago. As you know-- well,
you don't know--

I live in Boston. My mother was in her
early 80s, mid-80s,

and I'd flown back to visit her. And I would go back probably
four or five times a year.

She was in a little
community center there.

And one time I was listening
to this wonderful story

that she was telling me. She was telling me
about a person that

meant a lot to her that she
was in love with that had passed away in World War II.

And I was listening to her,
and it was just a great story. And all of a sudden, she
stopped, and she looked at me.

And she said, you know,
Tom, in this last hour,

you've looked at your
watch at least 10 times.

And the silence
was just like that, absolute silence between us.

There is no more guilt. What she did say was when
you come to visit next time,
could you keep your watch off? Just leave it in the car.

That's the first question--
that's the first story. The second story that will-- I'll connect with the story
about my mom a little bit

later. It's about a student, and
I'll call him Ranjeet. And Ranjeet came up to my--

I was teaching leadership
and organizational behavior. It was busy at the end of
the class, and he came up.

And I thought I had
terribly, and I also saw there's another
faculty member that wanted to come in and
get the boards all set.

And I was frustrated,
and he kept kind of just getting
too close to me.

And I snapped at him,
something to the effect of,

make an appointment,
or something to communicate that I
didn't have time for him.

Now why I care about
teaching and why I care about human
connection is that I

think that all
interactions are sacred, and that's the premise with
this book and the premise

and the theory behind why what I
attempt to do in the classroom.

And I believe that what we do
in Aldridge Hall here on campus

is-- in those classes,
it's hallowed ground.

So the question is
why would I allow

Tom to be focused on
the future or the past

and not be all
present, 100% present, if I actually believe that
human interactions are sacred?

So what I thought I'd do
is that everything I do in the classroom for an
80-minute class period

or a course with 30 sessions,
each of them 80 minutes long--

they're all based on this
notion of this the power of the human connection,
and what I can do,

and the kind of
person I can be so that student can learn as
much as she possibly can learn

and also have an experience. So what I'd like you to
do, before I give you this framework, I'd
like each one of you,

if you would, is
to recall a time or maybe recall the
face of a teacher who

made a significant difference
in your life, a teacher

that after you
left the classroom, you may have even felt different
about yourself positively.

It might have been three or
four years after that teacher that you went, oh
my, I realized that I

learned how to be at my best
or to be my best self of being with that teacher.

So I'd like you to just
put down the initials or write the name of the
person very kind of-- somewhere

and maybe two or three
of those attributes.

While you do that, I'm
going to put up a slide. Moriah was going to help
me with a slide that is

in the back of my head as I-- we'll go to the
next one that I'm

thinking about all the time. What I care about
is how am I going

to create a covenantal
relationship with students? What do I mean by that?

I mean that when they show up
and the minute class begins,

they are all in with
head, heart, and soul.

And I also know that their
heads and hearts could be in very, very different places.

There could have been
a death in the family. Someone might have fallen
out of love or in love.

Someone might be hung over. Interestingly, and I'm not going
to read much from the book,

but what I did was I
asked a few students to track their mind chatter,
their internal voice,

as they came into a class. This was a course on
being an authentic leader.

And listen to some of the
things that were kind of-- I'm thinking one
particular student.

This is what she's
thinking about. This is at 45 seconds
before class begins.

I'll go in through the
back entrance today. That way I can avoid making
eye contact with Emily.

It's not that I dislike her. It just feels awkward that
we shared dinner together

at least once a week last
year, and this year we've spoken just twice.

Ever since Emily's internship
in the fashion industry last summer, she mostly hangs
out with the rich kids' group.

She's not a bad person. The most down-to-earth
of that crew.

It's just that I'd
rather not run into her. That's at 40 seconds.
I'm going to skip to 20 seconds.

How selfish can I be? I'm thinking about
my evening plans tonight when I still haven't
called grandpa since he

had a minor stroke last week. Desmond reminded me every day. I wonder if all the other
grandkids have called

and if he thinks I
don't care about him. Too busy at HBS for family.

How typical. Call grandpa. I type it into my phone
before hastily turning it off.

Now I could go on,
but mind you, there are 90 students who have
internal dialogues going.

And one of the things I
attempt to do through-- when I start teaching
through a story

is to begin getting
them all in the room together where they can
experience the same breath,

and then we can begin
this adventure together. And so my goal is to create
a covenantal relationship

with them. How do I attempt to do this? And the research on teaching
as well as about leadership

relates with what I'm
going to talk about. So let's go to the first
thing that I want to list. These are the three
dimensions if we're

interested in having our
subordinates, if you're leaders, have covenantal
relationships,

or if we're teachers,
to have our students. One is how am I building
faith in the teacher?

Do I have faith in the teacher? And we'll talk later when
Deb's interviewing me. We'll talk a little bit
about that dimension.

The second piece is
how has that person--

how has that
teacher communicated that he cares or she cares
deeply about me and my work?

We know that since 1990, at
least in the business world, nothing has been taken of the
plate of leaders/managers.

It's only been additive. And so now it's so
unrealistic what we expect,

and sometimes we have those
same realistic expectations from our teachers.

So how am I going to
communicate that to that person? And if students feel
that and feel that the--

and have faith in the teacher,
then the third dimension also occurs. And that is the
students are focused

on learning and progressing,
and they're not just thinking about survival.

What's also important is there's
a correlation between having a covenantal relationship
in your classroom and high performance.

Now high performance might
mean very different things to different people based
on their competencies,

but they are lifted up. They're attempting to be,
again, their best self

in that context. And what also happens
is you continue to have the
psychological connection

through that covenantal
relationship. You'll see this here.

Now what happens is that-- let's go back to Ranjeet
my student or the student
that I had. So I snapped at him. I didn't go back to repair it.

He was a good
student, not great, but we were midway
through the course.

And I noticed him pulling away,
and going up the other door,

and not kind of
coming towards me, and I started to read into this
that something had happened.

There was a disconnection. And so what emerges,
what I would say-- and I talked to
him later about it.

Unfortunately, not then. I said, you basically
started to show up

with your head and
not your heart, and that's the movement
from covenant to contract.

And my goal, as a teacher,
is to be the kind of teacher,

know the subject et
cetera, et cetera, so that students feel
a covenant with me

for a number of
different reasons. I don't want them to simply
show up with their head

because if I'm trying to
model what a leader could be, if I'm asking them
to be future leaders,

they've got to figure out ways
that they are going to create covenantal
relationships to enhance

the organization and the
individuals within it. And now, again,
the last dimension

here is that when someone has
a contractual relationship and simply shows up
with her or his head,

then the dilemma is that
learning starts to decrease.

There is a pulling back,
and there's a disconnection. And if that happens enough
with enough people, enough

of your students, then you
have very different issues that you may want to deal with.

So that's one of the
organizing premises behind what

I attempt to do over a
semester and in my interactions with others.

Now I think it might be
more interesting for me to have a conversation
with Deb about it. And Deb has questions, or she
may ask questions about this.

But I'd invite her to come
in so that we can simply

have a conversation. And this isn't a
lecture from me. Thanks so much, Tom.

I know that you
are a keen observer of organizational
behavior and what

it takes to be a great leader. And you're an
incredibly keen observer of the teaching process, what
it takes to be a great teacher.

And you've asked us to think
about the most influential teachers or leaders
in our lives,

but I noticed very
early on in the book and actually
throughout the book you talk about Mr. Stickle,
your grade seven teacher.

And that still stands out to. I would say maybe it's
been a couple of years since you graduated
from grade seven.

Just a few. Just a few. And yet he still
stands out, just like I can remember my
kindergarten teacher, Miss

Hart. Of course, doesn't everybody
want a kindergarten teacher named Miss Hart?
So tell us what stands out?

One, Mr. Stickle knows content
and in our conversations

about history-- again, I was raised
in Portland, Oregon, so I was interested
in Lewis and Clark.

And he could tuck us on the
trail, the Oregon Trail,

and I felt like I was there. And when he talked
about each one

of the members of
that group having to eat six and seven
pounds of meat a day,

I still remember
that whole notion. And then when Lewis and Clark
get to the Columbia River,

it's the first time that we
really know about voting, and the women, and the folks
that were there to serve them.

They all got equal
votes to decide are we going to go
back now, or we going to wait the winter in Oregon?
So it's the way he told stories. The other thing is--

and if my siblings
were on, they know this is that my emotions
are close to my heart.

And I remember being made
fun of by some students, and I began to cry.

I was in seventh grade, and
I remember him taking me out on the playground, and those
were in the good old days.

He had a beautiful--  he always wore a beautiful
brown suit, white shirt,

and he smoked cigarettes. And I thought-- when you're 14,
you think that's really cool.

And he took me out
on the playground, then he took me on a walk. And I'll never forget the
walk that he just listened,
and he said it was OK to cry.  That's Mr. Stickle.

He gave me permission to be me
and not to be somebody else.

The other thing you said-- and
the picture, all your stories, and all your writing
just conjures up

such great pictures. And you said that
a teacher should

be like a mad
scientist who can't wait to get into the classroom
to share your experiment.

And I'm thinking of Back
to The Future, you know, with the white hair. So what does your
mad scientist look

like, and what are you
telling us to do as teachers? Well, I'm saying to be so
in love with your content

that there are
moments you actually-- you forget that you're
in the classroom when

you're describing a
particular concept. In organizational
behavior, there's

a concept around espoused
theory and the theory in use, meaning what are you
selling to people,

and then how are
you really living? And when I begin to talk about
the variance between what

you're espousing and then
how you're actually living, I sometimes-- I mean, I don't really forget.

But students look at me,
and I think later they say I didn't think
anybody could be so not crazy but so passionate.

But all it is is it's a theory. It's a theory about
organizational behavior and about how
individuals behave.

So I think that I need
to convince students, and I've read about it with
Tony Athos who's now passed,

and Jack Gabarro. And Lynn Schlesinger used
to tell me, you better convince the
students that you are

in love with your
content, the subject, and you're your love
with the students.

So that's part of
my mad scientist.

You also talk a lot
about and you're very-- you're constantly reflecting.

You're constantly assessing, and
you talked about your mindchat, the voices that are going on,
the chatter that's going on.

And you talk in the
book about the need to understand your
tendencies and habits

was with Joe Badaracco and
his book on reflections. So you're talking a lot about--

I'm hearing more and more
about taking the time to reflect, and to be
self aware, and then how

you can use those patterns. Do you want to talk a
little bit more about that?

So I don't know when I
began to observe this, but I started to
realize that I either

have a great day
or a terrible day, or if I read some evaluations
that say that I my--

a few students will
say, Professor Long, I'm a little frightened
of your humor, and I don't know how to read it.

And it frightens
me a little bit. Well, I can read that
and depending on my mood,

I can say, I'm the worst
teacher in the world. I mean, I'm a failure,
and so the pattern

that I've recognized
for a long time is I think about
things in either or.

It's either great,
or it's terrible. And now when Ranjeet,
when I blew him off

in an offensive way, at least
now I feel that way, once I

realized it, then I
thought that's awful. So when I walk out
of a classroom,

I'm typically thinking that
was really, really good, or I'm thinking it's
a one, it's, ah,

man, I'm really
frustrated with that. But that's a constant
pattern in my life

to live my life on tens and
ones instead of fours and sixes,

and I think it gets in the way. I think it gets in the way
because I expect everybody

in my life at school and at home
to adapt to whether I'm a 10

when I come home and
I've conquered the world, or one is I feel like a failure.
So that's one pattern.

I think another,
for me, is that I can be very pleasant
with people, and people have,
on occasion, said

that I can connect with others. But if somebody
confronts me or I feel

like I don't have
an answer, I'll have a tendency to get angry.

And I get angry not at a
one, but I'll get angry at a seven or an eight.

And those patterns,
by the way, show up in all parts of our lives. I mean, oldest
daughter, Sarah, said--

I said, well, did I really
yell when you were growing up? And she says, well, I think most
people would call it yelling.

But she said, we just figured
out how to manage around it, and then she says,
dad, I wouldn't want you to be any different.

But then she says,
isn't it interesting that I'm telling you
this when I'm 25? And I didn't tell you that
when I was 15, so that's--

those are two patterns that are
absolutely core to me that I need to manage every day.

I mean, I talk about core. I also talk about stylistic. Think, like, my need to move
in classroom, walk around.

For whatever reason, I
feel like it stirs up the energy in the
classroom, or perhaps

an overreliance on
narratives, on storytelling. That's something that I
think is a stylistic issue.

Yeah, you also bring
this the parallel between teachers as leaders
and leaders as teachers.

And I know in the
room we have teachers, and we have people from the
corporate or organizations.

And we have people like
me, who's both a teacher and an administrator so a
teacher leader in my role.

There's some parallels
too I see in that when you talk about curriculum
planning or curriculum

development. That almost sounds like
strategic planning to me, and you talk about
course development. And is that project planning?

And knowing your students, is
that being an inclusive leader?

Can you talk a little bit
about this great comparison?

The first piece-- and
it's alarming to me, and then I'll make
the connection--

is that I've talked to
hundreds and hundreds of CEOs, and senior managers,
and I haven't

had more than three or four who
have ever defined themselves or seen their role as teachers.

Really? That's not their
identity, and I'm

suggesting that's
one of the reasons that so many organizations are
dysfunctional because there's

something else on their
mind than what am I going to do today
to teach others

so they can be at their best? And so, yes, there are
some fundamental things

that teachers need to do, and
there's fundamental things that leaders need to do. And there's a lot of overlap.

For example, Paul
McKinnon, a dear friend, and I have used to model on
leadership for a lot of years.

And we simply say there's four
things you got to focus on. One is you've got
to set direction. Now you can call it strategy
or mission, but however--

whatever you want to
call, but you have to-- because humans
are goal directed, so you're going to do
that in both settings.

Then you need to get commitment
to it to that direction. How are you to get
people to buy in?

And then third is you've
got to execute on it. You need to implement. And then the fourth piece really
connects into the teaching

piece because I don't
think many folks have

memorable positive experiences
with leaders because they don't

see themselves as anything
but the head of the ship

or at the helm. And I'm suggesting that, can you
imagine-- see, what I think--

I have some letters,
a few letters, from students where they said,
Professor DeLong, thank you

for teaching us how to have
difficult conversations. Thank you for teaching us in
the course on human behavior

how not to delay
having a negative-- putting off conversations.

Well, to me, that's what
great teachers should do to teach those students to be--

when they leave, they'll
be great leaders, or they'll be better leaders
if they learn some more

interpersonal competence. Well, I could just
sit here and ask

you my 35 million questions,
and I was telling Tom that I had the luxury
of a block of time one

day where I sat and I read
the book from cover to cover. And that's very, very rare for
me to have that amount of time,

and so it was just a pleasure
to interact with that book. And as I said, I
could just keep going.

But as you may see in chat, we
have a boatload of questions, and I want to make sure
we get to some of those.

So let me transition to
some of these questions. And, again, some will
be kind of verbatim. Others will be a synthesis that
we've been putting together

as we're looking through
these incredible questions from Africa, and from Hawaii,
and from all over the world.

It's really quite exciting
to see so many people. So, first, and here
we are on Zoom,

is how you keep in touch
with students' hearts in this remote
learning environment?

Have things changed
for you there? First call I made when
our school shut down being

in person was a counselor. And I said, I think
I need to retire.

This was last March. I'd just come out of
an executive program where I taught with a
gifted teacher, Scott Snook.

And I called my therapist,
and I said, well, I think I need to retire because
I've just lost my superpower.

She goes, what are
you talking about? And I said, I've got
to teach over Zoom. And one of the things,
at least I've been told,

is that I can
connect with people, and I can create a
particular spirit. And I can't do that anymore.

And she said, you're
out of your mind. She says you haven't
taught over Zoom.

Give it a shot. So I've been giving it a shot,
and I think you can connect.

And I think the
literature on those-- for therapists, for example,
who report that they've

learned a lot about
a therapeutic model over Zoom where they
can, in fact, make

more progress in certain
situations with their clients. And so I think I can
say, no, it doesn't work.

The other thing I can do is I
can perhaps tell more stories, ask more questions.

But there's some
things I think that we can do to connect over Zoom.

Yeah, we have a manager at a
global advertising agency that

has had three rounds
of layoffs and is

about to go into a fourth. So this person is asking, how do
I keep my covenant relationship

with people when they are
scared of being the next let go?

Well, this is-- I'm just reflecting on the
person who sent this in.

A person that doesn't have
a covenantal relationship wouldn't send this thing in.

What I mean is that this person
has built up emotional capital.

Fear is one thing. Anger is another. And I believe that
if this person

has a covenantal relationship,
that people will give him or her benefit of the
doubt, and I would just
say keep connecting. Keep connecting. Pull the people closer to you.
Have more Zoom calls. Focus on proximity.

Maybe you increase the amount
that you are communicating

with these individuals,
but I don't think that those subordinates,
at the end of the day,

are blaming this
particular manager. And I think this manager,
who asked the question,

has to have more
faith in the ties that he's created
with these managers--
or with his subordinates. Yeah.

Here's another one. How can teachers
think about being vulnerable with their students
to deepen the relationship

while still
maintaining their role as an authoritative figure? Oh.

I guess it depends on what we
were talking about in terms of vulnerability.

If vulnerability means--
for me, mature vulnerability means saying things in class
like, I don't know, or to say,

I don't know how to
handle the situation, or this is the first time
I've ever heard that question.

What do you think? I don't think vulnerability
means groveling.

I don't think it means
sharing too much information,

but what I do believe is
that I think we always

are on the side of thinking
that we need to have an authoritarian relationship. You already do.

The question is, do
you need that to be an effective teacher? In other words, are you
talking to your students,

or are you talking
with your students? Are your students
frightened of you?

Do you want that? You just need to decide
in terms of your style

how much of that authority
figure dimension you need.

And I just think you may-- I would invite you just to
step back and say, what does it mean to you to be authoritarian
and also to be vulnerable?

It does not mean to share
everything about who you are, but it is to communicate and be
dead honest that you're real.

Here's a related question,
I think, is also around--

it's around performance issues. So you've done a lot of
work in talent management.

You do a lot of student
assessment, et cetera, so how do you deal with
performance issues

during COVID, especially
when people have suffered bereavement and still
have to deal with business

and I think you can
say learning pressures? So how does is time impacting
how we think about progress?

Well, I think it also depends
on the nature of the performance

if it's a serious problem. Is it a where someone's
had inappropriate--

done things that
they shouldn't do? Is it that the
person is simply not

performing at a certain level? I just think-- again,
I'm going to go back to this notion of
proximity and frequency,

and that is you just you
get in with the person and have a conversation
about, one, what can I do?

Or you ask the question,
when are you at your best, and how can I help you be there?

And how has the
organization let you down?

And if we were to work closely
together for the next two months--

now I would say
that at the tail end of a conversation if I know
there's been bereavement,

et cetera, et cetera. But I should know. If I have a covenantal
relationship with them, I'm going to know that.
